title: Teams vs Groups
content: A team is more than a group of people working in the same area. Teams have shared goals, interdependent tasks, and coordinated effort—each member's success depends on others. Groups can work in parallel with minimal coordination; teams must actively integrate their work. Understanding this distinction determines what coordination behaviors are necessary.

mcq.question: Five technicians work in the same facility, each handling their own customers independently. They share a break room and occasionally help each other. Are they a team or a group?

options.A: Team—they share a workspace and goals
options.B: Group—their work is independent, not interdependent

mcq.explanation: Despite shared space and occasional help, their core work is independent—one technician's success doesn't depend on coordinating with others. This is a group. A team would have interdependent tasks where coordination is essential to success.

openQuestions: Is your current work unit more of a team or a group? What makes you classify it that way?
What would need to change for a group in your organization to function as a true team?
